abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the eRwanda Project for
            Rwanda were as follows: outcomes were satisfactory, risk to
            development outcome was moderate, Bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory, and borrower performance was
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: Information and
            Communication Technology (ICT) buses are an innovative
            solution to reach to people in rural areas. The ICT buses
            have 20 laptop computer stations with an internet
            connection. In addition, the bus has a large monitor and DVD
            player, a projector and projector screen, and its own power
            generator. The ICT buses allowed youth and rural people, who
            do not have household electricity, an opportunity to become
            familiar with ICT by touching computers and using the
            internet. It provided opportunities to teach basic IT skills
            and promoted ICT awareness at the grass-root level. The ICR
            team concurred that ICT buses have a high potential to
            positively affect social development in Rwanda. In fact,
            this project aimed at mitigating gender digital divide by
            mandating at least 30 percent female participation in all
            training sessions in ICT buses. The eRwanda project took a
            unique approach to building local monitoring and evaluation
            (M&E) capacity. Under component 4 (Program Management),
            the project supported M&E courses at Kigali Institute of
            Science and Technology (KIST) in order to build local
            M&E capacity. Thanks to the participation of KIST
            students, the eRwanda team was able to conduct two
            large-scale user surveys (in 2008 and in 2010) with a
            limited budget. Equally important, the KIST students
            obtained first-hand survey experience. This collaboration
            created a win-win situation for both parties, and is a
            scenario to be replicated in other Bank projects. PROCYS
            (Procurement Cycle Tracking System) launched in Rwanda in
            November 2008 together with other pilot countries for the
            first phase in the Africa Region. e-Rwanda was among the
            first projects to use the system. The first request was sent
            through PROCSYS by eRwanda team in January 2009, 3 month
            after the system launch. The system was found very useful in
            terms of monitoring and tracking the procurement process,
            because all documents are saved in the same place in the
            system automatically. There is no need for the client to
            send hard copies to the Bank, since Task Team Leader (TTL)
            and other team members including Procurement Staff can
            access the system directly from anywhere. Also the system
            allows users to generate periodical monitoring reports. It
            contributed tremendously to reduce the time required for
            review and response on sides (Bank and Client) as well as
            procurement monitoring and management.

repnme.cdata!:
eRwanda project : end term monitoring and
            evaluation report

abstracts.cdata!:
The eRwanda project has focused on
            specific activities within the national information and
            communication infrastructure (NICI) plan with potentially
            the greatest impact on good governance and improved
            conditions for the country's citizens, particularly
            those most vulnerable, least economically advantaged and
            vast majority of citizens who live in the rural areas
            including women, farmers, and traders. The goal is to
            modernize the Rwandan economy and society into a knowledge
            based economy using information and communication technology
            (ICT) as the engine for accelerated development, economic
            growth, national prosperity, and global competitiveness.
            This final study (phase out survey) is a follow up to the
            2008 project baseline survey that was carried out to
            establish the starting point of the project. The main
            purpose of this study is to enable the project to establish
            how much it has impacted its stakeholders in relation to the
            outcomes it is trying to achieve that is, the status of the
            project's key performance indicators at the point of
            closure of the project. Data collection was done through
            face-to-face interview forms, self-administered
            questionnaires, electronic forms, and focus group
            discussions. Observation and probing were also used to
            obtain some of the required information and for verification
            purposes. This end term evaluation study was conducted among
            at least 3,394 respondents with the specific objectives to
            establish the existing ICT infrastructure and applications
            usage and distribution in government institutions, the
            public service delivery performance at government
            institutions, the awareness levels and exploitation of
            e-Governace among Rwandan citizens, and to establish the
            level of citizen's access to information and public
            services. After this assessment opinions were obtained from
            respondents on what services and on how best they think
            service delivery and information can be improved in the
            societies. The key services identified for improvement
            included infrastructure services, document processing,
            health services, education services, and general document processing.
